body: @ajbozarth would you please take this work. The issue is that some integration tests always throw unrelated exception from scalatest. Can you please investigate, thanks!
I was planning on taking this up, I actually did a bunch of leg work on this last spring, mostly trying to figure out that IT failure. I'll look into it and open up my own PR by early next week
Thanks!

Just a update, I am actively working on this but given I was unable to locate a branch or patch of my work from last year that addressed IT issues it's taking me time to re-track down the issues to fix them (it has been nearly a year since I last looked at it)
Thanks! Let me close this one.

@jerryshao I'll most likely be picking this back up once I open a PR for Scala 2.11, could I get some feedback on my previous comments to use as a jumping point? I'd like to get this done within the next work week, I've let it sit *WIP* too long.
Thanks @ajbozarth , I will review it soon.

Thanks for the feedback @jerryshao and @vanzin if there no other comments I'll merge this later today once tests re-pass
Since Travis is down I may have to merge this tomorrow

@jerryshao I'm about to start writing the script that will build then copy the API Docs into the Docs build and was wondering if you had a personal presence for language. For scripting my go-to is usually bash, but I could also use ruby like Spark or try python if you think using one of those would be better than bash. (I plan on writing the script tomorrow)

Sorry for late response. I don't have a personal preference on language, you can choose your own.

As to expose Java/Scala APIs, actually what we need to expose is only about Job APIs for Java and Scala. I don't think it is necessary to expose other modules like rsc. This exposes unnecessary details to the users, and makes us hard to refactor.
Currently Because we don't have a good scope definition for all the modules/classes, so I'm afraid building a javadoc will unnecessarily expose the internals.

If we'd rather not publish the java/scaladocs to the website then this is good to go as is (without the script). But I think having javadocs for at least the Job API is worthwhile. How about I allow users to build all the docs but the script (used for the website docs) will only build the Job API portion?

So I've made some updates as well as added a jekyll script to include the api docs

- Based on @jerryshao comments about the rsc module I created a `public-docs` build profile. I then moved the javadoc package restrictions there as well as added more so only the Java API docs are built with the profile. This also allows developers to build all the javadocs themselves if desired.
- I wrote a script that runs with a jekyll build that includes the Java API and Scala API docs with the Livy Docs build. This uses the above profile to only include the public API docs and not all of the javadocs and scaladocs
Now that tests passed I'll merge this
FYI I'm doing some refactoring after merging the Scala 2.11 update. Apparently 2.11.3 changed a bunch of WARNs into ERRORs for scaladoc

Hi @ajbozarth , I think what I was saying is that we don't need to build java doc for internal modules like rsc and others, because user will not touch it. For now I think only Java/Scala Job API related docs should be enough.

What do you think?
Yes, sorry if I wasn't clear. I have updated the pom so anyone can build any of the javadocs or scaladocs, _BUT_ only the Java/Scala Job API portions are included in the Livy Documentation build.
Yes, that's what I mean ðŸ˜„ .

So the 2.11 update has brought to light new frustrating limitations of scaladocs with maven. I plan on spending some time tomorrow trying to find a solution, if I can't I'll just update the build script to bypass the root build to get the Scala API docs and I'll remove references to Livy supporting scaladocs for the project.

I'm pushed my final update as well as updated the PR description to include noted issues with javadocs and scaladocs for future reference.

In the end Livy can't support scaladocs in every module after the update to 2.11 due to our fractured versioning in our code (supporting both 2.10 and 2.11) causing errors in the scaladoc build (previously in 2.10 they were warnings not errors). As such I have updated the Docs build script to build the Java and Scala API Docs directly inside their respective modules to bypass project-wide issues. If devs wish to build scala/javadocs themselves they can deal with imperfect/broken private docs.
@jerryshao could you take a final look at this? I'd like to include it in RC1 when i cut it next Monday
@jerryshao not to pester, but I was holding off rc1 for your ok this, if I don't hear from you by your next EOD then I'll just cut rc1 without this.
LGTM, sorry for the late response. Please go ahead.

@jerryshao this should address that issue that was brought to you. Once Travis passes, I'll merge this and open rc2. I'll also merge this to branch-0.4 but given it's an issue in the Docs I don't think it's worth pushing out a 0.4.1 release

In the mail, it says "Known * critical severity* security vulnerability detected in nokogiri <
1.8.1 defined in Gemfile.lock", do we need to upgrade to 1.8.1?

1.8.1 is just the latest version and Gemfile.lock already imports 1.8.0 directly, the issue is that html-pipeline depends on nokogiri version 1.4 or greater. My solution just makes sure that dependency uses 1.5.4 or greater instead (the version the vulnerability was fixed in). Given it was a dependency of a dependency I wanted to cause the smallest change possible, but I can alway change both lines to use 1.8.1 instead.
I see, thanks for explain.

AFAIK, Spark itself also doesn't support non-integer cores. How do you that Spark supports this non-integer cores, also what's the meaning of 0.1 cores?

CC @ajbozarth

Spark does not support non-Integer values. Those values are passed into Spark as String and converted to Integers, but even then passing it a double would fail the spark-submit. I'm not sure where you got the misconception, but I looked in the Livy and Spark code and the values you changed here definitely have to be Integers for the spark-submit to succeed.

They are Ints in the YARN implementations, but Doubles for Mesos and Kubernetes. In k8s, the cores values get translated into Kubernetes Pod resource requests, where fractional cores are a thing that makes sense :) This isn't something you would generally do in real jobs (unless the job wasn't CPU bound) but it matters for local development.

And I can 100% promise you this works with the k8s backend, it's the only way I can start a job in my 2 CPU dev VM (Kubernetes doesn't allow overcommit on requests, it will refuse to schedule things instead).
OK, I see, let me first check the code of Spark on Mesos and k8s.

https://github.com/apache-spark-on-k8s/spark/blob/branch-2.2-kubernetes/resource-managers/kubernetes/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/scheduler/cluster/k8s/ExecutorPodFactory.scala#L109 is the relevant code there :)

And I think https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/resource-managers/mesos/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/scheduler/cluster/mesos/MesosFineGrainedSchedulerBackend.scala#L62 is the relevant bit in Mesos land, but I don't know that side very well.

Thanks for those links, given those usages are in forks of Spark and not the main repo I'm a little bit hesitant, but I know we have talked about formally extending support for Meso in the future so I'd be ok with this change. I think we should confirm how Livy would handle Spark throwing a spark-submit error for a non-Int when using YARN/Standalone though. If the error is handled cleanly then I'm fine with this, otherwise we would address that in this PR.
Related to my above statement, if we're adding tests we should add a negative test as well to check that passing a string or some other value would not work.

Heh, the k8s branch/fork is getting upstreamed, that subsystem is already in actually https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/resource-managers/kubernetes/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/scheduler/cluster/k8s/ExecutorPodFactory.scala#L94

Wow, no idea how I missed that in my search results, on second look it's definitely there. We should support this then, but I stand by my comments about testing. We should check how Livy handles YARN and Standalone failing on double input as well as add a test that makes sure Livy won't take in non-numerical input.
I may need some pointers on where to add tests and how :) The few that I added was just tweaking some existing test code, I am still very much a n00b at this codebase.

So for the string Unit Test I figured you write it just like the ones you added. As for the other testing, you should try out your code change using Livy with YARN and Standalone and give it a Double or a String and see how it handles the error. In the case of String, that error is what your checking for in the above Unit Test. In the case of a Double, you should make sure that the error is handled safely and doesn't cause anything to crash or hang, if it does you'll need to address that in this PR.

Does that help you with next steps?

@jerryshao I made some update to your release script while doing 0.5, could you take a look. Also if you could try it in your own env, I did extra testing by inserting a `exit 0` before the svn block of code. Note I hav't tested the `publish-release` portion, so this should be merged until after I test that in the final release.
LGTM, thanks for the fix.

Okay, I added another pair of unit tests for the string case. I'm kind of surprised that Jackson is even willing to decode that kind of invalid value. I could make it more explicitly fail at decoding like is already done for the `kind` key if you are interested in that :)

As for how this will impact other modes, I did some digging through the Spark code I think the answer is "not much". On the submit side, all CLI parsing into the SparkConf is handled purely as strings. The only type checks come when retrieving values from the conf, so as long as you don't actually use a fractional core value with YARN, it should be fine (technically if you tried to assign more than 2<sup>53</sup> cores it would cause a problem because that can't be represented in a double with exact precision, but I think we're probably okay on that one). Local mode actually ignores the values entirely and will happily accept `--executor-cores banana`.
Thanks for the updates. As a followup though, even if it's "not much" what exactly would happen if you give a fractional core value to Livy when using YARN with your changes?

For batch requests, `spark-submit` will error out with a type coercion error when it calls `sparkConf.getInt('spark.driver.cores')`. I'm less clear on session/interactive requests and I don't have the environment to test it but I think it should be the same.
Ack, didn't mean to close, sorry.
So it will cause the initial submit to error and the Livy session would then be ended as FAILED?
Yep, definitely for batch sessions, probably (99%, unless I missed something in the code) for interactive.
Ok then I believe this LGTM, @jerryshao want to take one last look?
I will review again later today.
@jerryshao made a small updated to fix an issue I found while running `publish-release`
I wouldn't expect release package to be built on mac environment, so it is not necessary to fix.
But I just had to run it on a mac, my dev environment is my MacBook Pro.

You can install a virtualbox or something else. My concern about building on Mac is that some behavior maybe different regarding to native library. Since Mac will never be used in production. We'd better to keep the same environment for building and running.
@jakhani are you still willing to work on this? I know some users who would like to see this merged, but it still needs work.
Sorry for taking so much time in completing this PR. I am planning to work on this. I will submit review comment fixes in a week and close this PR.
Thanks @jakhani
Spark itself has issues to use fractional core numbers, see https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/20460. Let's wait until Spark itself fix such issues.
Nice catch @jerryshao I agree we should wait until Spark has that fix in.

From the issues in apache/spark#20460 I think we should close this out and pursue a different tack :) Probably leaving the main driver,executor.cores as ints and use secondary properties to allow more fine-grained control over k8s resource requests.

There is a problem when add unit test, since there is a scalastyle check rule:

`<check level="error" class="org.scalastyle.scalariform.NonASCIICharacterChecker" enabled="true"></check>`

I think this check rule is necessary, so we believe we cannot remove this rule.

Some improvements that might be necessary:
* whitelist for supported environment variables
    * currently it would be possible to set `PATH` before spark-submit
    * not sure this is completely secure 
    * could whitelist just `SPARK_HOME` and `SPARK_CLASSPATH` to start
    * an empty whitelist would disable this feature
* ensure that `SPARK_CLASSPATH` is only set when Spark is set to run in cluster mode
    * if running in client mode, `spark.driver.extraClasspath` controls the `spark-submit` classpath
    * Users will get an error if `SPARK_CLASSPATH` is set when running in client mode

@jerryshao I'm not sure why security want us to update to the latest version when the vulnerability was fixed 3 major versions earlier, but I updated the nokogiri dependency to use the latest version.
I also don't have the context about this issue. Let's follow what security asked.

You mean that `-Ptargz` is not worked, am I right?

> You mean that -Ptargz is not worked, am I right?

No. The -Ptargz profile works fine. But these lines in `assembly/assembly.xml` are useless:
```xml
<formats>
    <format>zip</format>
</formats>
```
 because they are overwritten by the `${assembly.format}` property in `assembly/pom.xml`.
Closing and reopening the PR because one build profile failed with a timeout.

Thanks @zjffdu , merging to master.
@risdenk Why do we only support batch session, I think it is also needed for interactive session, right?

Manually tested the current PR with changing SPARK_HOME during the request.

**Setup**
* Set `livy.file.local-dir-whitelist = /home/USER/test_livy` in `livy.conf`
* `export SPARK_HOME=/home/USER/sparks/spark-1.6.3-bin-hadoop2.6`

**Simple Python test file**
```python
from pyspark import SparkContext
sc = SparkContext()
print('Spark Version: ' + sc.version)
```

**Testing different `SPARK_HOME`**
SPARK_HOME not set
```bash
curl -i -XPOST http://$(hostname -f):8998/batches -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"file": "/home/USER/test_livy/livy.py"}'
# Spark Version: 1.6.3
```

SPARK_HOME set to Spark 1.6.3
```bash
curl -i -XPOST http://$(hostname -f):8998/batches -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"file": "/home/USER/test_livy/livy.py", "env" : {"SPARK_HOME": "/home/USER/sparks/spark-1.6.3-bin-hadoop2.6"}}'
# Spark Version: 1.6.3
```

SPARK_HOME set to Spark 2.2.1
```bash
curl -i -XPOST http://$(hostname -f):8998/batches -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"file": "/home/USERNAME/test_livy/livy.py", "env" : {"SPARK_HOME": "/home/USER/sparks/spark-2.2.1-bin-hadoop2.7"}}'
# Spark Version: 2.2.1
```

SPARK_HOME set to Spark 2.3.0
```bash
curl -i -XPOST http://$(hostname -f):8998/batches -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"file": "/home/USER/test_livy/livy.py", "env" : {"SPARK_HOME": "/home/USER/sparks/spark-2.3.0-bin-hadoop2.7"}}'
# Spark Version: 2.3.0
```
@jerryshao - I only needed it for batch sessions currently so started with that. If you or someone has pointers on where to start adding to interactive session I can look at that too.
For the completeness of PR, I think adding support of interactive session is also required.
@jerryshao - I took a stab at adding environment variable support for interactive sessions as well.
